thread.title: Travel Channel to explore Al Capone's life in Miami
thread.title_full: Travel Channel to explore Al Capone's life in Miami

author: Adrienne Cutway
title: Travel Channel to explore Al Capone's life in Miami
text:
Travel Channel to explore Al Capone's life in Miami Brian Unger and his "Time Traveling" group visit Al Capone's Palm Island mansion 
The Travel Channel's "Time Traveling with Brian Unger" will explore the Palm Island mansion where mobster Al Capone lived in the 1930s and '40s. 
The Travel Channel's "Time Traveling with Brian Unger" will explore the Palm Island mansion where mobster Al Capone lived in the 1930s and '40s. Travel Channel (tv network) Video: Travel Channel to explore Al Capone's life in Miami 
The Travel Channel will explore Al Capone's time spent in Miami during the 1930s and '40s on an episode of "Time Traveling with Brian Unger" set to air 8 p.m. Thursday. Caption Former Home Of Al Capone Refurbished In Miami Beach Joe Raedle / Getty Images The pool cabana is seen during a tour of the former home of Al Capone on March 18, 2015 in Miami Beach, Florida. The pool cabana is seen during a tour of the former home of Al Capone on March 18, 2015 in Miami Beach, Florida. (Joe Raedle / Getty Images) Caption Al Capone in Palm Island AP / File An undated photo shows Chicago mobster Al Capone on a fishing vacation off Palm Island, Fla. Visitors still come to Chicago from all over the world searching for anything to do with Capone, who died Jan. 25, 1947. An undated photo shows Chicago mobster Al Capone on a fishing vacation off Palm Island, Fla. Visitors still come to Chicago from all over the world searching for anything to do with Capone, who died Jan. 25, 1947. (AP / File) See more galleries 
The 30-minute show will use CGI to take viewers back in time as host Brian Unger and his crew visit Capone's home on Palm Island in Miami Beach, the bank where he kept his money, plus the Dade County Courthouse where he spent three days on trial . 
The notorious Prohibition-era mobster lived on-and-off in Miami starting in 1928 when he first bought his mansion for $40,000, according to the Miami Herald . He made around $200,000 in improvements and upgrades -- including adding a two-story cabana -- that made the Mediterranean-style home perfect for hosting decadent parties.
